content.body: Domenic: what prevents you from having a scripting relationship with a bfcache'd document? I guess there's some unspecified(?) magic that might kick it out of bfcache, but you can hold a reference just fine right?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: what prevents you from having a scripting relationship with a bfcache'd document? I guess there's some unspecified(?) magic that might kick it out of bfcache, but you can hold a reference just fine right?

content.body: annevk: right, I guess it's the fact that no browser bfcaches iframes or windows with openers. (Not a matter of kicking you out; they just never get bfcached in the first place.) Allowing that would probably break tons of specs that are not prepared for it. We offered to add this to the spec in the past but I think there wasn't appetite.
content.formatted_body: annevk: right, I guess it's the fact that no browser bfcaches iframes or windows with openers. (Not a matter of kicking you out; they just never get bfcached in the first place.) Allowing that would probably break tons of specs that are not prepared for it. We offered to add this to the spec in the past but I think there wasn't appetite.

content.body: Domenic: you don't need an opener to hold a reference to a nested document though
content.formatted_body: Domenic: you don't need an opener to hold a reference to a nested document though

content.body: TabAtkins: why would you define them as a new URL scheme and not a particular MIME type?
content.formatted_body: TabAtkins: why would you define them as a new URL scheme and not a particular MIME type?
